docs.lead_paragraph: It is Thursday, prenatal day at the storefront health clinic on Nostrand Avenue, in the heart of Caribbean Brooklyn. So the narrow, brightly lighted waiting room is packed with round bellies and aching backs, baby strollers and mothers-to-be patiently listening to lectures on the virtues of milk and cheese. Thirty-three women have appointments this day. The federal and state governments pay for them to consult with a nutritionist, sign up for free milk and infant formula and be examined by a midwife -- this one in a brown straw bowler.

headline.main: Appeal Pending, Immigrant Mothers-to-Be Crowd Prenatal Clinic

docs.abstract: Article discusses illegal immigrants that receive prenatal care at health clinic in Brooklyn; according to recent court ruling, they are not entitled to such care financed with federal money, however New York continues to receive federal aid for program; legal conundrum arises because, although mothers are not eligible for benefits, their babies are citizens and entitled to Medicaid; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Summit Leaders Pledge Money to Fight Diseases After protests in Genoa, Italy, leaders of the world's biggest economies sat down for the first time to discuss health, debt and the poor -- the topics that demonstrators have complained that rich countries ignore. The leaders announced that about $1.2 billion had been committed to a United Nations Global Health Fund that will fight AIDS, and other infectious diseases, following through on a commitment made at the summit last year in Okinawa, Japan. [Page A7.]

docs.lead_paragraph: The state insurance commissioner, Mike Kreidler, has proposed requiring state-regulated health insurers to include contraceptive coverage in their prescription drug benefits. Mr. Kreidler, a Democrat, says he expects the state to adopt the rule in September and insurers to include contraceptive coverage by January 2002. A Federal District Court decision in June and an Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ruling in December forced employers to include contraceptives in their drug plans; Washington would be the 15th state to require the same of insurance companies. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Inclusion On Contraceptives

docs.lead_paragraph: New York State's economy, which had been bucking the national economic slump, has slammed into a wall, losing jobs in the private sector in May and June, the first such back-to-back job declines since 1995. Employment also fell in New York City, which has been the powerhouse of the state economy in the last couple of years, according to new data from the New York State Department of Labor and the City Comptroller's office.

headline.main: BUOYANT ECONOMY OF NEW YORK STATE SHOWS A REVERSAL

docs.abstract: New data show New York State lost jobs in private sector in May and June, first back-to-back job declines since 1995; New York City also lost jobs; May's gain in jobs was revised to loss of 3,800 jobs and June's loss was 9,500 jobs, adjusted for seasonal factors; economists look at job growth as primary sign of economy's health and focus on private-sector employment because government jobs fluctuate for non-economic reasons; new economic data comes as some of biggest Wall Street companies warn they would slash even more jobs; job market is still better in New York State than in much of rest of country; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Constitutional Court rejected a move by the states of Bavaria and Saxony to block a law granting same-sex couples the right to marry. The ruling means that as of Aug. 1 gays and lesbians will be allowed to marry in state registry offices and share common surnames. They will also receive rights given heterosexual spouses in areas like inheritance and health insurance. Victor Homola (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Upholds Gay Marriages

docs.lead_paragraph: By many social, financial, educational and health measures, the well-being of America's children has been improving, according to a new report from the federal government. While children are still more likely to be living in poverty than adults, the child poverty rate has been dropping steadily. In 1999, 16 percent of the nation's children lived in families below the poverty line -- the lowest rate in two decades, and two percentage points less than in 1998.
docs.abstract: New report from federal government finds that child poverty rate in America has been dropping steadily, although children are still more likely to be living in poverty than adults; finds that in 1999, 16 percent of nation's children lived in families below poverty line, lowest rate in two decades and two percentage points less than in 1998; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The House Appropriations Committee voted along party lines today to support a White House plan that would have the Navy pay all the electricity bills for the official residence of Vice President Dick Cheney, the administration's energy point man. The 33-to-29 vote in the Republican-controlled committee came after Democrats denounced the plan as evidence of a double standard at a time when other Americans were struggling to pay their own energy bills. Republicans defended the idea as a way to simplify federal bookkeeping that would cost taxpayers nothing.

headline.main: Plan to Shift Utility Costs For Cheney Gains Ground

docs.abstract: Republican-dominated House Appropriations Committee votes 33-29 along party lines to support White House proposal to have Navy pay all electricity bills for Vice Pres Cheney's official residence, which is 33-room Naval Observatory mansion; Democrats see hypocrisy if Cheney insulates himself from energy prices; committee also approves amendment requiring health plans for federal workers to cover prescription contraceptives; Bush administration opposes measure (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two national organizations representing drugstores and pharmacists filed suit in federal court to block President Bush's plan to endorse drug discount cards issued to Medicare beneficiaries by private companies. The plaintiffs, the National Association of Chain Drug Stores and the National Community Pharmacists Association, said the government devised the program in secret meetings with private industry in violation of federal law. Robert Pear (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Apria Healthcare Group, which provides respiratory therapy and home health care services, said yesterday that its liabilities under a lawsuit could be as much as $9 billion in an investigation for overbilling the government. ''Apria considers these assertions and amounts to be unsupported legally and factually,'' it said in a document filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission with an update on the litigation and the investigation into accusations that it overbilled the government from 1995 to 1998. The company said the analysis in a lawsuit used a sampling that overstated the number and significance of problems in billing of Medicare and other government agencies.

headline.main: APRIA SAYS IN FILING LIABILITIES COULD REACH $9 BILLION

docs.abstract: Apria Healthcare Group says its liabilities under lawsuit alleging that it overbilled government from 1995 to 1998 could be as much as $9 billion (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The insurer St. Paul Companies said that a Georgia state court judge had thrown out an order suspending its license in the state over efforts to cut losses in its medical-malpractice liability business. The company said the judge, Gail S. Tusan of the Fulton County Superior Court, overturned the suspension ordered by the Georgia insurance commissioner, John Oxendine. The suspension came after St. Paul said it would not renew more than 1,200 policies up for renewal in June. St. Paul said its medical-malpractice business in Georgia pays out $1.79 in claims for every $1 in premiums it collects, compared with a nationwide claim payout of $1.40 for every $1.

headline.main: ST. PAUL SAYS COURT REVERSES SUSPENSION OF ITS LICENSE

docs.abstract: Judge Gail S Tusan throws out order suspending St Paul Companies' license in Georgia; suspension was ordered after company said it would not renew more than 1,200 medical-malpractice policies up for renewal in June (S)
